body:
> As was mentioned in the community meeting however - it seems like the OptionalPassthrough transformer can already do most of what we would want to do with the MultiplexTransformer though performing a grid search over its passthrough variable. (A solution which I was not aware of, thank you for bringing it up!)

I was aware! I faintly remember that I may have said, written, or thought that `OptionalPassthrough` is, content-wise, equivalent to a `MultiplexTransformer` with the transformer that is the parameter, and an `IdentityTransformer`. So, the `OptionalPassthrough` would be the special case, the other way round I think it does not work.

Although I´m not sure whether implementing it that way the best solution, it seems to me the two transformers - multiplexer, and `OptionalPassthrough` - are not obvious special cases of each other, interface-wise. It might still be good to have them implemented separately.

> it seems like the OptionalPassthrough transformer can already do most of what we would want to do with the MultiplexTransformer though performing a grid search over its passthrough variable. (A solution which I was not aware of, thank you for bringing it up!)

@miraep8, @aiwalter, can you explain how this would look like mathematically?

This claim does not seem correct to me. I do not think we can easily replace an instance of the `MultiplexTransformer` with `OptionalPassthrough`.

How would this work, formally? Can you give an example, let´s say, how we would replace a multiplexer over three transformers, A, B, C?

What you say in your comment in question 1, @miraep8, sounds like a formal refutation of the claim, at least for a specific claimed equivalence, "MultiplexTransformer(A, B, C) is equivalent to Pipeline(Opt(A), Opt(B), Opt(C))" (I suspect @aiwalter said sth along these lines?)

It is a refutation due to your argument which I think is correct: we could end up having more than one transformer in the pipeline, e.g., a chain of A, B, as a realization, if we would approach this via a chain with each transformer wrapped in `OptionalPassthrough`. This cannot happen in a `MultiplexTransformer`, hence the two constructs cannot be equivalent.

>  The way that springs to mind would be to create a separate ForecastingPipeline or a TransformedTargetForecaster for each pair, and then put all the pairs into a MultiplexForecaster?

That's how I would do it. I.e., `(A * B) | (C * D)`, where `A`, `C` are transformers, and `B`, `D` are forecasters. The dunder syntax would invoke the `MultiplexForecaster`, not the `MultiplexTransformer`, since the pipelines `A * B` and `C * D` are forecasters.

I can't think of an alternative that would be more compact and less confusing/cognitively complex/more user friendly at the same time.

> Identify any meaningful use cases that either a) something like a MultiplexTransformer could uniquely support or b) that are worth expanding the current OptionalPassthrough approach to support as well?

I think that already the simplest case, i.e., `A | B` , cannot be captured equivalently by a composition that involves only `OptionalPassthrough`. 
(except when `A` or `B` is trivial)

> Should we clean up (ie delete) the `DelegatedTransformer` code if we don't need it?

Yes, but I doubt that we do not need it.

> Lastly - I wonder if there is some way we can more easily inform people of the existence of OptionalPassthrough? (Clearly people know about it!! But I had missed it (which may of course just be on me)! Thoughts on a Documentation page which has all the various Pipeline/model selection components? (and related dunders?))

Yes! A "Pipeline" notebook. `examples/05_pipelines.ipynb` where all the neat facts about pipeliens are collected in one place, and which has a list and examples with all the components and dunders!

Someone needs to write it though... (cough)
I'm still busy with the "transformer" notebook and the "scientific reference", unfortunately.
... and all this was discussed in the 10min when I wasn't there?? You were busy, apparently...

> How would this work, formally? Can you give an example, let´s say, how we would replace a multiplexer over three transformers, A, B, C?

Let's take an example (below is not the actual code but more of a pythonic way of explaining the current concepts of sktime)
```python
transformers = [ 
 ("log", OptionalPassthrough(LogTransformer())),
 ("box", OptionalPassthrough(BoxCoxTransformer())),
]
# you can bundle up even upto 20 transformers like this

# lets say you have a model list
model_list = [
 ("arima", AutoArima()),
 ("ets", AutoETS()),
]
# you can also add many more forecasters in this model_list
```

From here, we challenged that the outcome and functionality of MultiplexTransformer + MultiplexForecaster 
will be same as what is achieved below
```python
best_forecaster = []
for model in model_list:
    pipe = transformers + model
    gscv_model = ForecastingGridSearchCV(forecaster = pipe, cv=cv, param_grid=param_grid)
    gscv_model.fit(y, fh)
    best_forecaster.append(gscv_model.best_forecaster_)

multiplex = MultiplexForecasters(best_forecasters, fh)
multiplex.fit(y, fh)

multiplex.predict(fh)
```
So having a class of MultiplexTransformer allows user to save this 5 to 6 lines of code. Which is why we were wondering what is the additional value of this besides convenience for the user.

@indinewton, can you kindly be more precise, and specify two *estimators* that would be equivalent?

You are outlining a manual process and not an estimator, and it seems you are not entirely on one page with @miraep8 on how the `MultiplexForecaster` would be used (or what it formally does). You would be doing `ForecastingGridSearchCV(MultiplexForecaster)`, not the other way round.

> a similar question/solution springs to mind in the case where we had a list of known transformations to use but we wanted to select the optimal ordering ie trans_a -> trans_b vs trans_b -> trans_a

Hm, depends on how many, and which combinations we want to select over.
If only some combinations, I would still use the multiplexer.

If all combinations, one could create a `PermutationPipeline`, which takes as parameters the transformers in the chain, and an element of the permutation group over the set of transformers. Although that feels impractical for anything except a small number of elements, due to combinatorial explosion.

> Question 1 - What if we want to use exactly 1 Transformer from a list of n transformers?. It seems to me with the current system if we did something like this (borrowed from the docstring example for OptionalPassthrough)

@miraep8 Actually this is currently not possible in sktime. Adding MultiplexTransformer will probably solve this, you are right.

> Then we could actually end up with a situation where we either skip both deseasonalizer and scaler or include them both. One might imagine it could be nice in some situations to specify that we want exactly one transformer from a list of transformers. Having a MultiplexTransformer is one way to achieve this...

Generally when we are building forecasting applications, we expect GridSearchCV to find answers for us. So if the answer would be _deaseasonlizer_ true and _scaler_ false, then that would be detected through GSCV. But what if user just wants to pick only one transformer and not more? That's not possible to control as of current sktime classes. So MultiplexTransformer will be helpful there.

Additionally after reading through rapidfire comments from @fkiraly, I also agree with below - 
> This claim does not seem correct to me. I do not think we can easily replace an instance of the MultiplexTransformer with OptionalPassthrough.

MultiplexTransformer will have more control over returned Transformers by controlling some parameter like return_n_best_transformers = 2. With OptionalPassthrough you can only benefit it when you wrap it in ForecastingGridSearchCV. So @fkiraly is right, actually. It seems it makes to add this in Sktime. So, the conceptual example I commented earlier, seems a bit out of context.
